> p-values can be replaced by constructing a 95% confidence interval around=
 the effect size (or 99%, or whatever confidence threshold we prefer) and s=
eeing if the confidence interval overlaps with 0.0. If it overlaps, it is n=
ot a significant effect; if it does not overlap, then we can claim that the=
re is a significant effect in the treatment.
> 
> Alternatively, if you don=
't like just showing effect size (or it is inappropriate for what you're pl=
otting), you can construct the 95% confidence interval around treatment A a=
nd treatment B's measurements. If they overlap at all, there is no signific=
ant difference; if they do not overlap at all, then there is a significant =
difference.
> 
> This is why I always plot means and 95% confidence interva=
ls in my manuscripts so it is visually straightforward to compare treatment=
s.
> 
> 
That sounds to me like you are just reinventing something very sim=
ilar to a p-value, and that serves the same purpose as a p-value=85.and als=
o falls prey to all the same objections that the post raised against p-valu=
es. I still haven't heard a good reason why p-values are not helpful when p=
roperly thought about (though I recognize that many don't think properly ab=
out them). 

Cheers,
Jeff



--Apple-Mail=_B7EA43A1-D56E-4285-9D4A-FB43395FF808

=3D"ygrp-msg" style=3D"z-index: 1;"><div id=3D"ygrp-text"><p>p-values can b=
e replaced by constructing a 95% confidence interval around the effect size=
 (or 99%, or whatever confidence threshold we prefer) and seeing if the con=
fidence interval overlaps with 0.0. If it overlaps, it is not a significant=
 effect; if it does not overlap, then we can claim that there is a signific=
ant effect in the treatment.<br>
<br>
Alternatively, if you don't like just=
 showing effect size (or it is inappropriate for what you're plotting), you=
 can construct the 95% confidence interval around treatment A and treatment=
 B's measurements. If they overlap at all, there is no significant differen=
ce; if they do not overlap at all, then there is a significant difference.<=
br>
<br>
This is why I always plot means and 95% confidence intervals in my=
 manuscripts so it is visually straightforward to compare treatments.<br>
<=

 are just reinventing something very similar to a p-value, and that serves =
the same purpose as a p-value=85.and also falls prey to all the same object=
ions that the post raised against p-values. I still haven't heard a good re=
ason why p-values are not helpful when properly thought about (though I rec=
ognize that many don't think properly about them). </div><div><br></di=
v><div>Cheers,</div><div>Jeff</div><div><br></div></div><br></span></body><=
